deliberation: Examined time phrase, genealogy, movement to Mizpah, and the meal. The only potentially figurative element is וַיֹּאכְלוּ שָׁם לֶחֶם יַחְדָּו (they ate bread together). In Biblical Hebrew לֶחֶם “bread” frequently stands by metonymy/synecdoche for the whole meal and the social act of table fellowship. No metaphor, simile, personification, hyperbole, or irony appears.

cultural association between sharing bread and sharing fellowship
conceptual mapping from food consumption to relational bonding
posture: narrator’s neutral description that assumes the cultural link between bread and fellowship
instances.explanation: “Bread” functions metonymically for the entire meal and for the act of table fellowship, a culturally significant sign of relationship and trust.

deliberation: Considered whether בַּחֶרֶב (“with the sword”) might be figurative for violent death in general, but in context it straightforwardly denotes the literal means of killing. The rest is plain narrative description of the assassination. No metaphor, simile, idiom, metonymy, or other figure stands out.

Narrative account of Ishmael killing Judeans and Chaldean soldiers. The verbs for striking and killing, and the references to people and place, are all literal. No lexical or phrasal figurative language (metaphor, simile, personification, metonymy, etc.) appears.

Describes temporal sequence (“the second day”) and the fact that no one knew yet. The phrasing וְאִישׁ לֹא יָדָע (“and no man knew”) could in some contexts be hyperbolic, but here it is best read literally (news of the murder had not yet spread). No clear figurative device is used.

Considered the mourning gestures (shaved beards, torn garments, gashes) as symbolic actions, but linguistically they are literal descriptions of physical acts. The phrase בֵּית יְהוָה (“the House of YHWH”) is a standard metonymy for the temple as YHWH’s dwelling and the locus of worship, not just an ordinary domestic ‘house’. No other figurative expressions detected.

theological perspective that emphasizes divine presence
instances.explanation: “House of YHWH” is a metonymy in which the domestic term ‘house’ stands for the temple as YHWH’s dwelling and the center of His worship.

deliberation: Ishmael goes out weeping as he walks and invites the men to Gedaliah. The weeping is deceptive in motive, but described literally; there is no explicit figurative comparison or idiomatic expression in the Hebrew. No metaphor, simile, metonymy, or personification detected.

The verse narrates their entry into the city and Ishmael’s slaughter of the men, casting them into the cistern. The language of slaughter and the cistern is concrete and literal. While the cistern later functions as a grim mass grave, the text states this straightforwardly. No figurative linguistic devices are clearly present.

Examined the plea for life based on hidden stores, and the phrase בְּתוֹךְ אֲחֵיהֶם (“in the midst of their brothers”). Here אֲחֵיהֶם ‘their brothers’ is not about literal siblings but a broader social group, ‘their fellows / compatriots’, an extended kinship term functioning metonymically for their group. No metaphor, simile, or hyperbole evident.

deliberation: Describes the specific cistern Asa made because of Baasha and notes Ishmael filled it with corpses. The filling is literal, not hyperbolic; the reference to earlier history is historical, not metaphorical. No clear figurative language devices are used.

Narrative of Ishmael taking captive the remaining people, including royal daughters, and heading toward the Ammonites. The verbs for taking captive and going over are standard and literal in this context. No metaphor, simile, metonymy, or idiom stands out beyond straightforward military-captive language.

Reports that Johanan and the army officers heard אֵת כָּל־הָרָעָה (“all the evil”) Ishmael did. הָרָעָה ‘the evil’ is a moral characterization but not figurative; it directly labels his deeds as wicked. No metaphor, simile, personification, or idiom appears.

Describes mustering men, going to fight, and meeting Ishmael by מַיִם רַבִּים אֲשֶׁר בְּגִבְעוֹן (“the great waters / large pool that is in Gibeon”). Though a similar phrase can be figurative elsewhere, here it is clearly identified as a known physical pool. Language is purely descriptive.

The verse recounts that all the people with Ishmael, seeing Johanan and the officers, rejoiced. Emotions (seeing, rejoicing) are stated literally. No figurative comparisons, personifications, or word-level metonymies are present.

Describes the people turning around from Ishmael and going to Johanan. The verb וַיָּסֹבּוּ (“they turned around”) could, in some contexts, be a metaphor for changing allegiance; here it describes literal physical movement together with a change of side, but the wording itself is straightforward action language. No distinct figurative expression is clearly marked.

Narrates Ishmael’s escape with eight men to the Ammonites. ‘Escaped’ and the movement verbs are literal; there is no figurative overlay (such as metaphorical flight, hyperbole, or idiom) present in the Hebrew wording.

Johanan and the officers take all the remaining people—warriors, women, children, eunuchs—whom he had brought back. The language is a straightforward catalog of persons and actions, without metaphor, simile, personification, or metonymy beyond ordinary referential use.

States that they went and stayed at Geruth Chimham by Bethlehem, on the way to enter Egypt. These are geographical and directional descriptions, literal rather than figurative. No metaphors, similes, or idioms are evident.

Explains that they did this מִפְּנֵי הַכַּשְׂדִּים כִּי יָרְאוּ מִפְּנֵיהֶם (“because of the Chaldeans, for they were afraid of them”). The preposition מִפְּנֵי (‘from before/because of’) contains a common spatial-to-causal extension, but this is regular grammar rather than a marked literary figure. The statement of fear and the causal link to Gedaliah’s death are literal. No salient metaphor, simile, hyperbole, or personification.
